title: KI2NA - Using Linked Data for the Intelligent society
segmentation: Good afternoon everybody and it's a pleasure to be here.
To my first European Data Forum in terms of the role that I have within Fujitsu.

Yes, it looks at research, but key to the role is to look at the commercial opportunities and to develop the type of business model that we need to put in place that converts research, whether it be in linked data or in other forms into revenue producing models that can.
Initiate revenue back to the company to further invest in the research that we wish to get involved with.
In terms of Fujitsu, we have what's called a human centric approach.
As a society we are facing huge challenges.
The population is growing and that leads to larger challenges for us in terms of transport.
In terms of healthcare and obviously in terms of data.
So we have large amounts of data being produced.
How do we start delivering new value for people?
Who do we?
How do we integrate those technologies into people's everyday lives so that they can use that technology and deliver the value that they need from it?
In terms of doing that, Fujitsu has research all around the world.
We are based in.

Our headquarters are in Tokyo where we have about 1500 researchers, but overall we've about 18 and a half thousand people worldwide involved in R&D activities in relation to the research here in Ireland we are involved with Japan, the UK and with research institutes from Ireland with a team of about 11 people in relation to the linked data research specifically focused on looking at the.
Applications of linked data and delivering applications that can obviously realize applications for Fujitsu Laboratories.
In terms of wider than that, we have a healthcare collaboration which is looking at collecting data using sensor based technology so.

In terms of the research we have, we have a link data application or link data project and then we have the sensor based technology as as we said the link data technology is related to what Steven does within the Institute in formally Jerry, but now insight and he will talk a little bit about the technology that were developed.
Yes, Anthony said Vegito's idea.
Another fee is human centric intelligence society and when Fujitsu came to ask the question was what could we actually contribute to this?
So what is it that we can enable it and it looks from a semantic mapping data perspective.
Very clear obvious answer, which is what we are aiming.
It ultimately is to create a network of data which is interlinked and if.
There should be a human centric intelligence SoC that technology ultimately disappears and just is there to serve us instead of being in the front and for fun in our fair face all the time for sure.
What thing that is necessary is that the data is not siloed anymore, but in fact works together seamlessly as seamlessly.
Then technology can work with us, so it's about.

In a network of data of knowledge, which again is interconnected, universal, all encompassing and I've shown this slide a couple of times, this ultimately is our core motivation for the link data approach.
It's not necessary is a database, of course what we're aiming to do with it, and there's link data.
Ultimately, the foundation for this network knowledge for integrating it, so we saw, and that's what we proposed with this widget to was.

Look at Link data as an enabling technology for the human centric intelligence society powering up that ultimately many of the ideas that are coming out and and I am going to realize this intelligent intelligence society.
This human centric intelligence.
Society.
But ultimately, data is just that, it's just sitting there, and it may be linked or not, but that's ultimately not relevant if you want to do something with it, you still have to process it.
You have to do something with it, and, well, it's a network of knowledge, very much like like the web.
So it's all the challenges that which are associated with that as well.
It's faulty and messy, and people are contributing to it, so different perspectives are in there, so we need to do something.
With it so in the end of the day, we need to manage it.
We need to provide abstraction, reasoning another tixan we need to visualize, collaborate and exploit it and do this with a scalable framework.
Something that enables us to do.
Like companies like Fujitsu enable companies like those to build the applications to focus on the intelligent SoC.
So in seamless and integrated way.
That's the motivation for the joint project, with Fujitsu still going all the way from from data to ultimately do something with it.
But ultimately then also into into commercial practice.
So it also putting it and leading it into products.
So one.
Core output of this project is a kitsune, a platform, so knowledge integration to enable network application.
Incidentally, kids who now meaning collaboration as Anthony pointed out, so it's ultimately a platform that will enable Fujitsu to create applications in ever in a number of different domain domains.
An entity is going to talk about those as well, so this platform is taking up many of the existing technologies.

Witch witch witch witch witch around for awhile which I've developed in European Union projects in single projects which we have already worked on for a number of years and package it in up in a way that enables us to create these.
These applications that take care of the fundamentals of data management but also of cleansing, filtering, conversion and mapping.

So one concrete output, for example, just to enable people to maybe provide a better way to search the current linked open datacloudisnotforall.net, in which there is a more dynamic version of the linked open Data cloud available for people to browse to filter and to select it.
There's a constant subject of improvement, but it's it's available and people can play with it already.
Right now, if they won't do it, this one particular was built by Fujitsu lapse in Europe, in in in the UK as part of the of the project.
But there are other parts as well, like for example uniform data processing layer.
We know very well that the majority of the data and if you want to be realistic about this is not linked and will not all be LinkedIn in a long time there CSV data.
One of the reasons why the W 3 CFTVT is now called data and not not semantic Web anymore.
And we need to take care.
I need to bring those particular datasets also into the family.
Need to be able to use it to do something with it.
So one idea in the project which we are building is a uniform query and processing layer which yes use this link data in a very very fundamental way.
But the idea is very much to Interlink and create and use many other different storage systems.
And and data formats in.
Yeah, legacy data.
Just continuing it.
Text exploration, extracting information from text an enabling the navigation fundamental part of leveraging existing data.
Part of this particular.
Project the number of different cortex needs like knowledge discovery and relation learning, which in particular relevant for healthcare applications is part of that.
This part is all components which we are packaging together to enable Fujitsu to build those.
Those application with that when it comes to the application Interactive business site, I'm heading over to Anthony again.
Thank you Steven.

OK, so it's it's all well and good having linked data, but one of the core requirements of the project is to start looking at the applications and one of the first applications that we've looked at is in the financial area and it's bringing together at link data and sentiment analysis to look at a different repository's of data, financial data and deliver new value out of it.
Both static data and marrying that with sentiment analysis to give it an element of real time and market assessment of a particular company.
And this has been very attractive because it's showing the value to the Fujitsu business of the use of linked data and we've now progressed that we've known progressed this application.
We're also now moving into the healthcare area and we're looking at drug reactions and the interaction of different drugs and the relationship between those drugs.
So already we're seeing.
The types of applications that we can have and the types of applications that could deliver revenue producing models into.
Fujitsu, and that's one of the key areas is what type of business model can we build to enable us to start developing these applications?
And that's a real challenge.
It's something that everybody is struggling with.
I hear people here struggling with the same issues as well struggling with how can we convert big data into revenue?
Steven spoke about it this morning and business value is a very big.
It's a key message from my CEO and it's a key message for Fujitsu as a Corporation and therefore we were bringing together our business units.
America's intelligence an air research excellence the likes of Stephen Decker and the team that he has to start looking at.
How can we use Link data to go into new markets?
And if differentiate the products that we are delivering.

And that's key by targeting what what we're looking at here, which is social challenges, whether it be healthcare would be finance or whether it's it's it's a public open data, so that we're delivering new insight through the applications that we're delivering that people are standing back and saying this is a very unique way of using data to extract new value, and it is hopefully allows us to achieve the type of market differentiation that will allow us to become a market leader and to transform the business that we have firstly in Ireland.
And then globalised as we start to move these products out from a a testbed in Ireland and start to use those on it on a global basis.
And that's very important for us that it gives us the global differentiation to places in a new market environment to allow us to grow our business.
In terms of the future, well, the future is obviously that we need to reach out beyond Ireland, and we've done that in terms of the research that we're doing at the moment, in that we are involving.
Obviously Japan were involving the UK, but now we're involving other business units in Poland and in Germany and in the UK, but we see Horizon 2020 as a.
A key enabler to reaching out to those people, like yourselves that are working with whittling data and the challenges of linked data.
And we're actively now looking at the various calls and the various aspects of Horizon 2020 and as a closer alignment between the Intelligent society and the different calls.
One of the streams of calls around the Information Society.
Obviously we have to develop that business model, and that's a key.
A key enabler for us to develop that model, and it's a key challenge, and it's not easy.
It's how do you bring together research and development in order to develop these applications.
In the most effective way possible we're making, we're obviously getting some advice from the likes of Stephen.
We're getting industry advice, but it's to get that perfect model that allows us to do that.
And that's something that is it going to be a key outcome from the research itself, and then it's early adoption.
We see that the involvement of our business units and of customers from the onset of the research which we have done at the moment is key.
It's critical so that we are developing the types of products that customers want.
That our business units want and that will allow us to realize the revenue and then one key element that has come out of the research is we need to think about a new type of analytical tool.
At the moment tools we talked about Steven spoke about data scientists this morning.
Yes, data Sciences are very important, and for it's an important skill set, but we need to be able to open that up.
We need people to stand the people business people to be able to drill down and look at this data and understand it.
So one key element is to cooperate or to collaborate with business units looking at.
Business analytical tools that we can develop and create that allow people to mine data and deliver the value that we need.
Thank you.
